verses.text: When they had appointed elders for them in every church, with prayer and fasting, they commended them to the Lord in whom they believed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they passed throughout Pisidia and came to Pamphylia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and when they had preached the word in Perga, they went down into Attalia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there they sailed to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work which they had completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived and had assembled the church, they reported what God had done through them and how He had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And there they stayed a long time with the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men came down from Judea and were teaching the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised in the tradition of Moses, you cannot be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore when Paul and Barnabas had no small dissension and dispute with them, they determined that Paul and Barnabas, and certain others among them, should go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and elders about this question.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So being sent on their way by the church, they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, declaring the conversion of the Gentiles, and they brought great joy to all the brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church and the apostles and the elders, and they declared what God had done through them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some believers of the sect of the Pharisees rose up, saying, “It is necessary to circumcise them, and to command them to keep the Law of Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The apostles and elders assembled to consider this matter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After much disputing, Peter rose up and said to them, “Brothers, you know that some time ago God decided among us, that by my mouth the Gentiles should hear the word of the gospel and believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God, who knows the heart, approved of them, giving them the Holy Spirit just as He did to us,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and made no distinction between them and us, and purified their hearts by faith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, why test God by putting a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we have been able to bear?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we believe that through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ we shall be saved, even as they.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire assembly remained silent and listened to Barnabas and Paul declaring what signs and wonders God had done through them among the Gentiles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had become silent, James answered, “Brothers, listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Simon has declared how God first visited the Gentiles to take from among them a people for His name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With this the words of the prophets agree. As it is written:
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
that the rest of men may seek the Lord,
    and all the Gentiles who are called by My name,
says the Lord who does all these things.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Known to God are all His works since the beginning of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore my judgment is that we should not trouble those of the Gentiles who are turning to God,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but that we write to them to abstain from food offered to idols, from sexual immorality, from strangled animals, and from blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Moses has had in every city since early generations those who preach him, being read in the synagogues every Sabbath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then it pleased the apostles and the elders, with the whole church, to send chosen men from among them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas, namely, Judas called Barsabas, and Silas, leading men among the brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They wrote this letter by their hand:
The apostles and the elders and the brothers,
To the brothers who are of the Gentiles in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia:
Greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since we have heard that some of us, whom we did not commission, have gone out and have troubled you with words, unsettling your minds, saying, “You must be circumcised and keep the law,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: it seemed good to us, being assembled in unity, to send chosen men to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: men who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore we have sent Judas and Silas, who will also speak to you, saying the same things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to put on you no greater burden than these necessary things:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abstain from food offered to idols, from sexual immorality, from strangled animals, and from blood. If you keep yourselves from these, you will do well.
Farewell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when they were dismissed, they went down to Antioch. And when they had assembled the congregation, they delivered the letter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had read it, they rejoiced over the exhortation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judas and Silas, being prophets themselves, exhorted the brothers with many words and strengthened them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had remained there for a time, they were sent off in peace by the brothers to the apostles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But it seemed good to Silas to remain there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After some days Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us return and visit our brothers in every city where we preached the word of the Lord and see how they are doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barnabas determined to take with them John, who was called Mark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul thought it was not good to take with them one who had withdrawn from them in Pamphylia and had not gone with them to the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then there arose a sharp contention, so that they separated from each other. Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but Paul chose Silas and departed, being commended by the brothers to the grace of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he came to Derbe and then to Lystra. A disciple was there, named Timothy, the son of a Jewess who believed, but his father was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was well spoken of by the brothers who were at Lystra and Iconium.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul wanted him to travel with him. So he took him and circumcised him because of the Jews who were in those places, for they all knew that his father was a Greek.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they went through the cities, they delivered to them the decrees to observe, that were set forth by the apostles and elders at Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the churches were strengthened in the faith, and increased in number daily.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went through the region of Phrygia and Galatia and were forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came near Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit did not allow them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they passed by Mysia and went down to Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night a vision appeared to Paul: A man of Macedonia stood and pleaded with him, saying, “Come over to Macedonia and help us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had seen the vision, immediately we sought to go into Macedonia, concluding that the Lord had called us to preach the gospel to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Troas we set sail on a straight course to Samothrace and the next day to Neapolis,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and from there to Philippi, which is the main city of that part of Macedonia, and a colony. We stayed in this city several days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the Sabbath we went out of the city to a riverside, where prayer was customarily offered. And we sat down and spoke to the women who had assembled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A woman named Lydia, a seller of purple fabric of the city of Thyatira, who worshipped God, heard us. The Lord opened her heart to acknowledge what Paul said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she and her household were baptized, she entreated us, saying, “If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come to my house and remain there.” And she persuaded us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On one occasion, as we went to the place of prayer, a servant girl possessed with a spirit of divination met us, who brought her masters much profit by fortune-telling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She followed Paul and us, shouting, “These men are servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to us the way of salvation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She did this for many days. But becoming greatly troubled, Paul turned to the spirit and said, “I command you in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her.” And it came out at that moment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her masters saw that the hope of their profits was gone, they seized Paul and Silas, and dragged them into the marketplace to the rulers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they brought them to the magistrates, saying, “These men, being Jews, greatly trouble our city
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and teach customs which are not lawful for us, being Romans, to receive or observe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The crowd rose up together against them. And the magistrates tore the garments off them and gave orders to beat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had laid many stripes on them, they threw them into prison, commanding the jailer to guard them securely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having received such an order, he threw them into the inner prison and fastened their feet in the stocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken. And immediately all the doors were opened and everyone’s shackles were loosened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the jailer awoke and saw the prison doors open, he drew his sword and would have killed himself, supposing that the prisoners had escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul shouted, “Do not harm yourself, for we are all here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called for lights and rushed in, trembling, and fell down before Paul and Silas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then led them out and asked, “Sirs, what must I do to be saved?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus Christ, and you and your household will be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And they spoke the word of the Lord to him and to all who were in his household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that hour of the night he took them and washed their wounds. And immediately he and his entire household were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought them up to his house and set food before them. And he rejoiced with his entire household believing in God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was day, the magistrates sent the sergeants, saying, “Release those men.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prison guard reported these words to Paul, saying, “The magistrates have sent to release you. Now therefore depart, and go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Paul said to them, “They have publicly beaten us, who are uncondemned Romans, and have thrown us into prison. And now do they secretly throw us out? Certainly not! Let them come themselves and bring us out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sergeants reported these words to the magistrates, and they were afraid when they heard that they were Romans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they came and entreated them. And they brought them out, asking them to leave the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went out of the prison and entered the house of Lydia. When they had seen the brothers, they exhorted them and departed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: According to his custom, Paul went in, and on three Sabbaths he lectured to them from the Scriptures,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: explaining and proving that the Christ had to suffer and to rise from the dead, and saying, “This Jesus, whom I preach to you, is the Christ.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of them were persuaded and joined with Paul and Silas, including a great crowd of devout Greeks and many leading women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Jews who did not believe became jealous and, taking some evil men from the marketplace, gathered a crowd, stirred up the city, and attacked the house of Jason, trying to bring them out to the mob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some brothers to the city officials, crying out, “These men who have turned the world upside down have come here also,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Jason has received them. They are all acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They troubled the crowd and the city officials when they heard these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had taken a bail payment from Jason and the rest, they released them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas away by night to Berea. When they arrived, they went into the synagogue of the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, for they received the word with all eagerness, daily examining the Scriptures, to find out if these things were so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore many of them believed, including honorable Greek women and many Greek men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews of Thessalonica learned that the word of God was preached by Paul at Berea, they came there also, stirring up the crowds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The brothers immediately sent Paul away to the sea. But Silas and Timothy remained there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who escorted Paul brought him to Athens and departed with instructions for Silas and Timothy to come to him quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Paul waited for them in Athens, his spirit was provoked within him as he saw that the city was full of idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore he disputed in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons, and in the marketplace daily with those who happened to there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers encountered him. And some said, “What will this babbler say?” Others said, “He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign gods,” because he preached Jesus and the resurrection to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took hold of him and led him to the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what this new doctrine is of which you speak?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you are bringing strange things to our ears. Therefore we want to know what these things mean.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For all the Athenians and foreigners who lived there spent their time in nothing else, but either telling or hearing something new.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul stood in the middle of the Areopagus, and said: “Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are very religious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For as I passed by and looked up at your objects of worship, I found an altar with this inscription:
TO THE UNKNOWN GOD.
Whom you therefore unknowingly worship, Him I proclaim to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God who made the world and all things in it, being Lord of heaven and earth, does not live in temples made by hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nor is He served by men’s hands, as though He needed anything, since He gives all men life and breath and all things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has made from one blood every nation of men to live on the entire face of the earth, having appointed fixed times and the boundaries of their habitation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that they should seek the Lord so perhaps they might reach for Him and find Him, though He is not far from each one of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘For in Him we live and move and have our being.’ As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are His offspring.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore since we are the offspring of God, we ought not to suppose that the Deity is like gold or silver or stone or an engraved work of art or an image of the reflection of man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God overlooked the times of ignorance, but now He commands all men everywhere to repent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For He has appointed a day on which He will judge the world in righteousness by a Man whom He has appointed, having given assurance of this to all men by raising Him from the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some scoffed. But others said, “We will hear you again concerning this matter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Paul departed from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, some men joined him and believed. Among them were Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla, because Claudius had commanded all the Jews to leave Rome. And he went to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And because he was of the same trade, he remained with them and worked, for they were tentmakers by trade.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He lectured in the synagogue every Sabbath and persuaded Jews and Greeks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Silas and Timothy came from Macedonia, Paul was pressed by the Spirit and testified to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they opposed him and blasphemed, he shook out his garments and said to them, “Your blood be upon your heads. I am innocent. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he departed from there and entered the house of a man named Justus, one who worshipped God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord with his entire household. And many of the Corinthians, who heard, believed and were baptized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Paul in the night through a vision, “Do not be afraid, but speak and do not be silent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I am with you, and no one shall attack you and hurt you, for I have many people in this city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So for a year and six months he sat among them, teaching the word of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews in unity attacked Paul and brought him to court,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, “This man is persuading men to worship God contrary to the law.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul was about to speak, Gallio said to the Jews, “O Jews, if it were a matter of a misdemeanor or serious crime, I would rightly bear with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if it is a question of words and names and your law, look into it yourselves. For I do not intend to be a judge of these matters.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he drove them out of court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the judgment seat. But none of these things mattered to Gallio.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet Paul remained many days. He had his hair cut in Cenchrea, for he had taken a vow. Then, bidding farewell to the brothers, he sailed to Syria, and Priscilla and Aquila were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He arrived at Ephesus and left them there. But he himself went into the synagogue and lectured the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they asked him to remain for a while longer, he did not consent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but, bidding farewell, said, “I must by all means attend this upcoming feast in Jerusalem, but I will return to you if God wills.” And he set sail from Ephesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had landed at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church and then went down to Antioch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After spending some time there, he departed and passed through the entire region of Galatia and Phrygia in sequence, strengthening all the disciples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile a Jew named Apollos, born in Alexandria, who was an eloquent man and powerful in the Scriptures, came to Ephesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man was instructed in the way of the Lord, knowing only the baptism of John, but being fervent in spirit, he accurately spoke and taught the things concerning the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue. When Aquila and Priscilla heard him, they took him and explained the way of God more accurately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Apollos intended to pass into Achaia, the brothers wrote to encourage the disciples to welcome him. On arriving, he greatly helped those who had believed through grace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he vehemently refuted the Jews publicly, proving from the Scriptures that Jesus was the Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Apollos was at Corinth, Paul passed through the upper regions and came to Ephesus. He found some disciples
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and said to them, “Have you received the Holy Spirit since you believed?”
They said to him, “No, we have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to them, “Into what then were you baptized?”
They said, “Into John’s baptism.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “John indeed baptized with the baptism of repentance, telling the people that they should believe in the One coming after him, that is, in Christ Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they spoke in other tongues and prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were about twelve men in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for three months, lecturing and persuading concerning the kingdom of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when some were hardened and did not believe, but spoke evil of the Way before the crowd, he withdrew from them and took the disciples, lecturing daily in the school of Tyrannus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This continued for two years, so that all who lived in Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God worked powerful miracles by the hands of Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So handkerchiefs or aprons he had touched were brought to the sick, and the diseases left them, and the evil spirits went out of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some of the itinerant Jewish exorcists invoked the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, “We command you to come out in the name of Jesus whom Paul preaches.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were seven sons of a Jewish high priest named Sceva doing this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The evil spirit answered, “I know Jesus, and I know Paul, but who are you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man in whom the evil spirit was jumped on them, overpowered them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled from that house naked and wounded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This became known to all Jews and Greeks living in Ephesus. And fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many who believed came confessing and telling their deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many who practiced magic brought their books together and burned them before everyone. They calculated their value, which equaled fifty thousand drachmas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the word of the Lord powerfully grew and spread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things happened, Paul determined in his spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia and go to Jerusalem, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent two who ministered to him, Timothy and Erastus, into Macedonia, but he delayed in Asia for a time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: About that time great trouble arose about the Way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a silversmith named Demetrius, who made silver shrines for Artemis, brought much business to the craftsmen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gathered them together with the workmen of similar trades and said, “Men, you know that by this trade we have our wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you see and hear, not only at Ephesus, but almost throughout all Asia, that this Paul has persuaded and turned away many people, saying that these things made by hands are not gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now not only is our trade in danger of coming into disrepute, but also the temple of the great goddess Artemis, whom all Asia and the world worship, may be discredited and her magnificence destroyed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they were full of anger and cried out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city was filled with confusion. And in unison they seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Paul’s traveling companions from Macedonia, and rushed into the theater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul intended to go in among the crowd, the disciples would not let him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even some of the rulers of Asia, who were his friends, sent to him begging him not to venture into the theater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The assembly was confused. Therefore some cried out one thing and some another, and most of them did not know why they had come together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews pushed Alexander to the front as the crowd prompted him. Alexander motioned with his hand, wishing to make his defense to the mob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they learned that he was a Jew, for about two hours they all with one voice cried out, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city clerk quieted the crowd and said, “Men of Ephesus, what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the guardian of the temple of the great Artemis and of the image which fell from heaven?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seeing then that these things are undeniable, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you have brought these men here who are neither temple robbers nor blasphemers of your goddess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So if Demetrius and the craftsmen who are with him have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. Let them press charges against one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you seek anything further, it shall be settled in the legal assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For we are in danger of being charged with rioting today, since there is no reason we may give to account for this uproar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the uproar ceased, Paul summoned the disciples and embraced them and departed for Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had gone through that region and had greatly exhorted them, he arrived in Greece,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and stayed there three months. When the Jews plotted against him as he was about to sail to Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Accompanying him to Asia were Sopater of Berea, and Aristarchus and Secundus of Thessalonica, Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy, and Tychicus and Trophimus of Asia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men went forward and waited for us at Troas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we sailed away from Philippi after the Days of Unleavened Bread, and after five days we came to them at Troas, where we stayed for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day of the week, when the disciples came together to break bread, Paul, ready to leave the next day, preached to them and continued his message until midnight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were many lamps in the upper room where they were assembled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A young man named Eutychus sat in the window, falling into a deep sleep as Paul spoke for a longer time. Being overcome by sleep, he fell down from the third floor and was taken up dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul went down and leaned over him, and embracing him said, “Do not be troubled, for he is alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had gone up and had broken bread and eaten, he conversed for a long while until dawn and departed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took the lad in alive and were greatly comforted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We went ahead to the ship and sailed to Assos, intending to take Paul on board there. For he had arranged this, intending to go on foot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he met us at Assos, we took him on board and went to Mitylene.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day after sailing from there we arrived off Chios. And the next day we crossed over to Samos and stayed at Trogyllium, and the following day we came to Miletus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul had decided to sail by Ephesus, to avoid spending time in Asia. For he was hurrying so he could be in Jerusalem, if possible, on the day of Pentecost.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Miletus he sent to Ephesus for the elders of the church.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to him, he said to them, “You know how I always lived among you from the first day that I came to Asia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: serving the Lord with all humility and with many tears and trials which befell me through the plots of the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I did not keep from declaring what was beneficial to you, and teaching you publicly and from house to house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: testifying to both Jews and Greeks of repentance toward God and of faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, compelled by the Spirit, I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what shall befall me there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me in every city that imprisonment and afflictions await me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But none of these things deter me. Nor do I count my life of value to myself, so that I may joyfully finish my course and the ministry which I have received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the gospel of the grace of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now I know that all you, among whom I went proclaiming the kingdom of God, will see my face no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore I testify to you this day that I am innocent of the blood of all men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I did not keep from declaring to you the whole counsel of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore take heed to yourselves and to the entire flock, over which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to shepherd the church of God which He purchased with His own blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I know that after my departure, dreadful wolves will enter among you, not sparing the flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even from among you men will arise speaking perverse things, to draw the disciples away after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore watch, remembering that for three years night and day I did not cease to warn everyone with tears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, brothers, I commend you to God and to the word of His grace, which is able to build you up and give you an inheritance among all who are sanctified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have not coveted anyone’s silver or gold or clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, you yourselves know that these hands have provided for my necessities and for those who were with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all things I have shown you how, working like this, you must help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus, how He said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having said these things, he knelt down with all of them and prayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all wept much and embraced Paul’s neck and kissed him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: grieving most over the words he spoke, that they were to see his face no more. Then they escorted him to the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we had withdrawn from them and set sail, we went on a straight course to Cos, the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We found a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, went aboard, and set sail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having come in sight of Cyprus, we passed to the south of it and sailed to Syria, and landed at Tyre, for there the ship’s cargo was to be unloaded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we found the disciples, we remained there seven days. They told Paul through the Spirit not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when our days were over, we parted and traveled on. Everyone, with wives and children, escorted us until we were outside the city. And we knelt on the shore and prayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After bidding farewell to one another, we boarded the ship, and they returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We finished the voyage from Tyre when we landed at Ptolemais, where we greeted the brothers and stayed with them for one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we who were Paul’s companions departed, and arrived at Caesarea, and entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had four virgin daughters who prophesied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While we stayed there many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had arrived, he took Paul’s belt and bound his own hands and feet, saying, “The Holy Spirit says, ‘In this manner the Jews at Jerusalem shall bind the man who owns this belt and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we heard these things, both we and the residents implored him not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be imprisoned, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he would not be persuaded, we kept silent and said, “Let the will of the Lord be done.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After those days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us and brought with them Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we had come to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the next day Paul went with us to James, and all the elders were present.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He greeted them and recounted one by one what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they heard this, they glorified the Lord. Then they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who believe, and they are all zealous for the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have been informed concerning you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children nor to observe the customs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What then shall be done? The assembly will certainly meet, for they will hear that you have come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore do what we tell you. We have four men who have taken a vow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take these men and be purified with them, and pay their expenses so that they may have their heads shaved. Then all will know that what they were told concerning you is nothing, but that you yourself live in observance of the law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the Gentiles who believe, we have written and concluded that they should observe no such thing, except that they abstain from food offered to idols, from sexual immorality, from strangled animals, and from blood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then on the next day, Paul took the men and purified himself with them. And he went into the temple, announcing when the days of purification would be complete and an offering would be given for each one of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the seven days were nearly concluded, the Jews from Asia saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people, and laid hands on him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man teaching all men everywhere against the people and the law and this place. He even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they supposed Paul had brought into the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the whole city was provoked, and the people ran together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple. And immediately the doors were shut.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were trying to kill him, news came up to the commander of the battalion of soldiers that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He at once took soldiers and centurions, and ran down to them. When they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the commander came and arrested him, and ordered that he be bound with two chains. Then he asked who he was and what he had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some in the crowd shouted one thing, some another. As he could not learn the truth because of the uproar, he commanded that he be brought into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came onto the stairs, he was carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the mob of people followed, crying out, “Away with him!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the commander, “May I speak to you?”
He replied, “Do you know how to speak Greek?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Are you not the Egyptian who in past days caused an uproar and led the four thousand men of the Sicarii out into the wilderness?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus of Cilicia, a citizen of no common city. I beg of you, permit me to speak to the people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had given him permission, Paul stood on the stairs and motioned with his hand to the people. When there was great silence, he addressed them in the Hebrew language, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Brothers and fathers, hear my defense which I now make to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When they heard that he addressed them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet.
Then he said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am a Jew, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city. At the feet of Gamaliel I was trained in the strict tradition of the law of the fathers, being zealous toward God as you all are today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I persecuted this Way to the death, arresting and imprisoning both men and women,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as even the high priest and the council of elders bear witness of me. From them I received letters to the brothers in Damascus, where I went to take even those who were there and lead them in chains to Jerusalem to be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As I journeyed and came near Damascus, about noon suddenly a great light from heaven shone around me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you persecute Me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I answered, ‘Who are You, Lord?’
“He said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who were with me saw the light and were afraid, but they did not hear the voice of Him who was speaking to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’
“The Lord said to me, ‘Rise and go into Damascus. There you will be told what you have been appointed to do.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since I was blinded by the glory of that light, those who were with me led me by the hand into Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Ananias, a devout man according to the law, who was well spoken of by all the Jews living there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: came and stood by me, and said, ‘Brother Saul, receive your sight.’ And at that moment I looked up at him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then he said, ‘The God of our fathers has appointed you to know His will and to see the Just One and to hear His voice,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for you will be His witness to all men of what you have seen and heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now why do you wait? Rise, be baptized and wash away your sins, and call on the name of the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and saw Him saying to me, ‘Hurry! Get out of Jerusalem immediately, for they will not receive your testimony concerning Me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I said, ‘Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat those who believed in You in every synagogue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And when the blood of Your martyr Stephen was shed, I was standing by consenting to his death, guarding the clothes of those who killed him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then He said to me, ‘Depart, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They listened to him up to this word, and then they lifted up their voices and said, “Away with such a man from the earth, for he is not fit to live!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they shouted and threw off their garments and threw dust into the air,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the commander ordered him to be brought into the barracks and examined with scourging, so that he might learn what crime they were alleging against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they stretched him forward with straps, Paul said to the centurion standing by, “Is it legal for you to flog an uncondemned Roman citizen?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On hearing this, the centurion reported to the commander, saying, “What are you doing? This man is a Roman citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The commander came and said to him, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?”
He said, “Yes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The commander answered, “I bought my citizenship for a large sum.”
So Paul said, “But I was born a citizen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore those who were about to examine Paul immediately backed away from him. And the commander feared, knowing that he was a Roman citizen and because he had bound him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the next day, desiring to know exactly why he was accused by the Jews, he released him and ordered the chief priests and all the Sanhedrin to assemble, and he brought Paul down to stand before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul looked at the Sanhedrin and said, “Brothers, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The high priest Ananias ordered those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul said to him, “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! Do you sit judging me according to the law, yet order me to be struck contrary to the law?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those who stood by said, “Do you criticize God’s high priest?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “Brothers, I did not know that he was the high priest. For it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil of the ruler of your people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul, knowing that one sect were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, cried out among the Sanhedrin, “Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of a Pharisee. I am being judged for my hope in the resurrection of the dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had said this, dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit. But the Pharisees acknowledge them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a great outcry. The scribes that were from the sect of Pharisees stood up and argued, “We find no evil in this man. But if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When much dissension arose, fearing that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, the commander ordered the soldiers to go down and take him from them by force and bring him into the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following night the Lord stood by him and said, “Take courage, Paul. For as you have testified about Me in Jerusalem, so you must also testify at Rome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At daybreak some of the Jews conspired under oath, saying they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were more than forty who had conspired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have bound ourselves under oath not to eat until we have killed Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, with the Sanhedrin, tell the commander to bring him down to you tomorrow, pretending to inquire further concerning him. We are ready to kill him before he arrives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the son of Paul’s sister heard of the treachery, he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Paul called one of the centurions over and said, “Take this young man to the commander, for he has something to tell him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he took him to the commander and said, “Paul the prisoner sent for me and asked me to bring you this young man who has something to tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the commander took him by the hand, went aside privately, and asked him, “What is it you have to tell me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The boy said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down tomorrow to the Sanhedrin, pretending to inquire further concerning him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not trust them. More than forty men, who have bound themselves with an oath to neither eat nor drink until they have killed him, are waiting for him. And now they are ready, waiting for your promise.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The commander dismissed the young man and ordered him, “Tell no one that you have reported these things to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he summoned two centurions and said, “Prepare two hundred infantrymen, seventy mounted soldiers, and two hundred light infantrymen with spears to go to Caesarea at the third hour of the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And provide mounts so Paul may ride and take him safely to Felix the governor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wrote a letter that went like this:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Claudius Lysias,
To His Excellency Governor Felix:
Greetings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them. When I learned that he was a Roman citizen, I came with soldiers and rescued him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Being minded to learn what crime they alleged, I took him to their Sanhedrin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I found him being accused of controversial matters about their law, but charged with nothing worthy of death or imprisonment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When it was revealed to me that there was a plot against the man, at once I sent him to you and ordered the accusers to state before you their charges against him.
Farewell.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the soldiers, according to their orders, took Paul by night to Antipatris.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day they let the cavalry depart with him and they returned to the barracks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they arrived in Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Upon reading the letter, the governor asked what province he was from. When he learned that he was from Cilicia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he said, “I will hear you when your accusers also arrive.” And he ordered that he be guarded in Herod’s Praetorium.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After five days Ananias the high priest arrived with some of the elders and a lawyer named Tertullus. They brought before the governor their charges against Paul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he was summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, “Since through you we enjoy much peace, and your foresight is bringing reforms to this nation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with all thankfulness, most excellent Felix, we always welcome it everywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But not to detain you further, I beg you to briefly hear us in your patience.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We have found this man a troublemaker, instigating riots among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He even tried to profane the temple. So we seized him and wanted to judge him according to our law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the commander, Lysias, came to us and forcefully took him out of our hands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ordering his accusers to come before you. By examining him yourself you will be able to learn about all these things concerning which we accuse him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Jews assented, alleging these things to be true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the governor motioned to him to speak, Paul answered, “Knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation, I cheerfully defend myself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may verify that it is no more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did not find me in the temple or in the synagogues or in the city disputing with anyone or stirring up a crowd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They cannot prove the things concerning which they now accuse me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I affirm that in accordance with the Way, which they call a sect, I worship the God of my fathers and believe everything written in the Law and in the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have hope in God that there will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust, which they also expect.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this do I always strive to have a clear conscience toward God and toward men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now after many years I came to bring alms and offerings to my nation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when some Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with a crowd nor an uproar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They ought to be here before you to accuse me if they have any charges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Or let these men say what crime they found in me when I stood before the Sanhedrin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: unless it is concerning this one statement which I cried out while standing among them, ‘Concerning the resurrection of the dead, I am being judged by you this day.’ ”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Felix, who had more exact knowledge concerning the Way, had heard this, he adjourned the proceedings and said, “When Lysias the commander arrives, I will decide your case.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he ordered the centurion to guard Paul, and to let him have liberty, and to forbid none of his own people from attending to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After several days, when Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was a Jewess, he sent for Paul and heard him speak concerning faith in Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he lectured about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix was afraid and answered, “For now, leave! When time permits, I will send for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the same time he hoped that money would be given him by Paul, that he might release him. So he sent for him more often and conversed with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But after two years Porcius Festus succeeded Felix. And Felix, desiring to do the Jews a favor, left Paul imprisoned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now three days after Festus had come into the province, he went from Caesarea up to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The high priest and the elders of the Jews spoke to him against Paul. And they begged him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: asking as a favor against him, that he would summon him to Jerusalem, plotting to kill him along the way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus said that Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he himself intended to go there shortly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also said, “Let the men in authority go down with me. If there is anything wrong in the man, let them accuse him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Having stayed among them more than ten days, he went down to Caesarea. And the next day he sat on the judgment seat and ordered that Paul be brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him and brought many serious charges against him which they could not prove,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while he defended himself, saying, “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I sinned at all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Desiring to do the Jews a favor, Festus answered, “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem to be judged concerning these charges before me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “I am standing before Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be judged. I have done no wrong to the Jews, as you know very well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I am doing wrong or have done anything worthy of death, I do not refuse to die. But if these are empty charges of which these men accuse me, no one may deliver me to them. I appeal to Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Festus had conferred with the council, he then answered, “To Caesar you have appealed. To Caesar you shall go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After several days King Agrippa and Bernice arrived at Caesarea to welcome Festus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had been there many days, Festus stated Paul’s case to the king, saying, “There is a man left as a prisoner by Felix.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me about him, asking for a sentence against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I answered, ‘It is not the custom of the Romans to deliver any man to die before he who is accused meets the accusers face to face and has the opportunity to make his defense concerning the charge brought against him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when they assembled here, without delay I sat on the judgment seat the next day and ordered that the man be brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the accusers stood up, they brought no accusation against him of such crimes as I had supposed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they had disagreements with him about their own religion and about a Man named Jesus, who had died, but whom Paul asserted was alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Being perplexed about such questions, I asked if he would be willing to go to Jerusalem and be tried there concerning these charges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Paul had appealed to be under guard for the decision of Caesar, I ordered that he be secured until I could send him to Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Agrippa said to Festus, “I would like to hear the man myself.”
He said, “Tomorrow you shall hear him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp, and they entered the hall with the commanders and the leading men of the city. When Festus gave the order, Paul was brought in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Festus said, “King Agrippa, and all the men who are present with us, you see this man, concerning whom the whole assembly of the Jews petitioned me, both at Jerusalem and here, shouting that he ought not to live any longer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death. But when he himself appealed to Caesar, I decided to send him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have nothing to write to His Majesty concerning him. Therefore I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that upon examination, I might have something to write.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For it seems unreasonable to me to send a prisoner without signifying the charges against him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You are permitted to speak for yourself.”
So Paul stretched out his hand and made his defense:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that today I shall make my defense before you against all the accusations of the Jews,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: especially because you are an expert in all customs and controversies of the Jews. Therefore I beg you to patiently listen to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My manner of life from my youth, spent from the beginning in my own nation and at Jerusalem, is known by all the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They knew me from the beginning and could testify, if they wished, how according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived as a Pharisee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now I stand on trial for hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, as they earnestly serve God day and night. Concerning this hope, King Agrippa, I am accused by the Jews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why is it judged incredible by you that God raises the dead?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I, too, thought that I must do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: which I indeed did in Jerusalem and locked up many of the saints in prison by authority from the chief priests. And when they were killed, I cast my vote against them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I punished them often in every synagogue and compelled them to blaspheme. And being extremely enraged against them, I persecuted them even to foreign cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So I went to Damascus with authority and a commission from the chief priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At midday, O King, I saw along the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those who journeyed with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why do you persecute Me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I said, ‘Who are You, Lord?’
“He said, ‘I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But rise and stand on your feet. For I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you as a servant and a witness both of what you have seen and of what I will yet reveal to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will deliver you from your people and from the Gentiles to whom I now send you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to open their eyes and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in Me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but declared first to those at Damascus, then at Jerusalem and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God and do works proving their repentance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For these reasons the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore having obtained help from God, I continue to this day, testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said would happen:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that the Christ must suffer, that He would be the first who would rise from the dead, and would announce light to His own people and to the Gentiles.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So as he made his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, “Paul, you are mad. Much learning is turning you to madness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “I am not mad, most excellent Festus. I speak the words of truth and reason.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, before whom I also speak freely, knows about these things. For I am persuaded that none of this is hidden from him, for this was not done in a corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “You almost persuade me to be a Christian.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said, “I pray to God that not only you, but all who hear me this day, might become not only almost, but thoroughly and altogether, what I am, except for these chains.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had said this, the king rose, as well as the governor and Bernice and those who sat with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had gone aside, they said to one another, “This man is doing nothing deserving death or imprisonment.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was decided that we should sail into Italy, they handed Paul and some other prisoners over to a centurion of the Augustan Regiment, named Julius.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Boarding a ship from Adramyttium, we put out to sea, meaning to sail along the coasts of Asia. Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, was with us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day we landed at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and gave him leave to go to his friends and be given care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there we put out to sea and sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sailing across the sea off of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing to Italy, and he put us on board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We sailed slowly for many days, and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, and as the wind did not allow us to proceed, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sailing past it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near the city of Lasea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As much time had been lost and as the voyage was now dangerous, because the Day of Atonement was already over, Paul advised them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, “Men, I perceive that this voyage will be with injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and ship, but also of our lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the centurion was persuaded more by the captain and the owner of the ship than by what Paul said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the harbor was not suitable to winter in, the majority decided to sail on from there, if somehow we might reach Phoenix, a harbor in Crete, facing southwest and northwest, and winter there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a south wind blew gently, supposing that they had obtained the necessary conditions, they weighed anchor and sailed along the shore of Crete.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But soon afterward a tempestuous wind swept through, called the Euroclydon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the ship was overpowered and could not head into the wind, we let her drift.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Drifting under the lee of an island called Cauda, we could scarcely secure the rowboat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had hoisted it aboard, they used ropes to undergird the ship. And fearing that they might run aground on the sand of Syrtis, they let down the mast, and so were driven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We were violently tossed by the storm. The next day they threw cargo overboard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day we threw the tackle of the ship overboard with our own hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small storm was upon us, all hope that we should be saved was lost.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they had long abstained from food, Paul stood in their midst and said, “Men, you should have listened to me and not have set sail from Crete, incurring this injury and loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I advise you to take courage, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there stood by me this night the angel of God to whom I belong and whom I serve,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul. You must stand before Caesar. And, look! God has given you all those who sail with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, men, take courage, for I believe God that it will be exactly as it was told to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless, we must be shipwrecked on a certain island.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the fourteenth night came, while we were drifting in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors supposed that they were approaching land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took soundings and found the water to be one hundred and twenty feet deep. When they had gone a little farther, they took soundings again and found it to be ninety feet deep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fearing that we might run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for day to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sailors strove to abandon ship and lowered the rowboat into the sea, under the pretext of lowering anchors out of the bow,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, “Unless these sailors remain in the ship, you cannot be saved.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the rowboat and let her fall off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As day was about to dawn, Paul asked them all to eat, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day that you have waited and continued without food, having eaten nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I urge you to eat. This is for your preservation, for not a hair shall fall from your head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had said this, he took some bread and gave thanks to God in the presence of them all. And when he had broken it he began to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they were all encouraged, and they also ate food themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all we were two hundred and seventy-six persons on the ship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and threw the wheat into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was day, they did not recognize the land. But they noticed a bay with a shore, into which they were determined to run the ship if possible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Casting off the anchors, they left them in the sea while loosening the ropes that secured the rudders. Then they hoisted the mainsail to the wind and made for shore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But striking a sandbar where two seas met, they ran the ship aground. The bow stuck and remained immovable, but the stern was broken up by the violent surf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The soldiers’ plan was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim away and escape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, prevented them from their intent and ordered those who could swim to abandon ship first and get to land,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the rest on planks or on pieces of the ship. And in this way they all escaped safely to land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had escaped, they learned that the island was called Malta.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The natives showed extraordinary kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because of the rain and the cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper driven out by the heat fastened on his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the natives saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, “Surely this man is a murderer. Though he has escaped from the sea, justice does not allow him to live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he shook off the creature into the fire and suffered no harm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They expected him to swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But while they waited and saw no harm befall him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In that area was an estate of the chief man of the island, named Publius, who had welcomed us and courteously housed us for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with a fever and dysentery. Paul visited him and, placing his hands on him, prayed and healed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this happened, the rest on the island who had diseases also came and were healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They honored us in many ways. And when we sailed, they provided us with necessary supplies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three months we sailed in an Alexandrian ship whose figurehead was the Twin Brothers, which had wintered at the island.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Landing at Syracuse, we waited there for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there we circled around and sailed to Rhegium. After one day the south wind blew, and the next day we arrived at Puteoli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we found brothers, and were invited to remain with them for seven days. And so we went to Rome.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there, when the brothers heard of us, they traveled as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we arrived at Rome, the centurion handed the prisoners over to the captain of the guard. But Paul was allowed to remain by himself with the soldier who guarded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three days Paul called the leaders of the Jews together. When they had assembled, he said to them, “Brothers, having done nothing contrary to our people or the customs of our fathers, I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had examined me, they were determined to release me, because there was no charge against me deserving death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not that I had any charge to bring against my nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this reason I have asked to see you and speak with you, because I am bound with this chain for the hope of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “We have not received any letters from Judea concerning you, and none of the brothers that have come have reported or spoken any evil of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we think it is proper to hear from you what you think. For concerning this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had arranged a day to be with him, many came to him at his residence. From morning until evening he explained and solemnly testified of the kingdom of God to them, persuading them concerning Jesus from both the Law of Moses and the Prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some believed what was said, but some did not believe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Being in disagreement with one another, they were dismissed after Paul had said one word: “The Holy Spirit accurately spoke to our fathers through Isaiah the prophet,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
for the heart of this people has grown dull.
    Their ears are hard of hearing,
    and they have closed their eyes,
lest they should see with their eyes
    and hear with their ears
    and understand with their heart
and turn, and I would heal them.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore let it be known to you that the salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles. They will hear it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had said these words, the Jews departed and disputed greatly among themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Paul remained two whole years in his own rented house. He welcomed all who came to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: boldly and freely preaching the kingdom of God and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.speaker: Narrator
